title: A quick guide to what opinions Reddit tolerates and what opinions they hate.

body: I would personally skew everything another 1/2 level to the Left, but overall a pretty good depiction. We are at the stage where posting a video of an event that happened, or citing/linking a statistic from a governmental website is considered "hate" and get you outright banned. Not sure how an objective fact or statistic is considered Left or Right, but they will ban you nonetheless.
body_html: I would personally skew everything another 1/2 level to the Left, but overall a pretty good depiction. We are at the stage where posting a video of an event that happened, or citing/linking a statistic from a governmental website is considered "hate" and get you outright banned. Not sure how an objective fact or statistic is considered Left or Right, but they will ban you nonetheless.

post.title: A quick guide to what opinions Reddit tolerates and what opinions they hate.

body:
It's the banning which is alarming. The upvote/downvote system doesn't work and thus they implemented a sprawling sluice to fixate their content according to investor and company policy. 

They banned The_Donald MONTHS after the community abandoned ship to thedonald.win. The community predicted this shit and avoided it. You can't fight the company paying for the server time. 

But hey, this site is something to be seen. Perhaps invest that energy into the community on this website. Maybe that left-right scale turns out to be irrelevant?
body_html:
It's the banning which is alarming. The upvote/downvote system doesn't work and thus they implemented a sprawling sluice to fixate their content according to investor and company policy.

They banned The_Donald MONTHS after the community abandoned ship to thedonald.win. The community predicted this shit and avoided it. You can't fight the company paying for the server time.

But hey, this site is something to be seen. Perhaps invest that energy into the community on this website. Maybe that left-right scale turns out to be irrelevant?

post.title: A quick guide to what opinions Reddit tolerates and what opinions they hate.

body:
I agree the comparison is hyperbolic and stupid.

But, to play devil’s advocate, his appeal is his opposition to a corrupt government that no longer serves the people. He positions himself as one man against an army of insiders that must root them out and “drain the swamp”. He also likes grand images and trying to restore America to its former glory. And he’s in a position where the people could give him a mandate to seize more power.

So it’s not entirely out of no where. But you could say the same thing about Obama. He ran on “change”, which was his version of “drain the swamp”. He positioned himself as a messianic leader to lead the country past a troubled time. He increased public works and surveillance. He portrayed his constituents as unfairly oppressed by corrupt money makers, and seized executive power through executive orders.

Trump is definitely closer because of his aesthetics and his nationalism than Obama, but both comparisons are superficial. In terms of actual policy and what his administration is trying to do, which is what actually matters, he’s nothing like him.

Encouraging national pride and wanting to advocate for the interests of citizens over foreigners != concentration camps and the gestapo.
body_html:
I agree the comparison is hyperbolic and stupid.

But, to play devil’s advocate, his appeal is his opposition to a corrupt government that no longer serves the people. He positions himself as one man against an army of insiders that must root them out and “drain the swamp”. He also likes grand images and trying to restore America to its former glory. And he’s in a position where the people could give him a mandate to seize more power.

So it’s not entirely out of no where. But you could say the same thing about Obama. He ran on “change”, which was his version of “drain the swamp”. He positioned himself as a messianic leader to lead the country past a troubled time. He increased public works and surveillance. He portrayed his constituents as unfairly oppressed by corrupt money makers, and seized executive power through executive orders.

Trump is definitely closer because of his aesthetics and his nationalism than Obama, but both comparisons are superficial. In terms of actual policy and what his administration is trying to do, which is what actually matters, he’s nothing like him.

Encouraging national pride and wanting to advocate for the interests of citizens over foreigners != concentration camps and the gestapo.

body: I'm personally borderline alt-left but I just got tired of reddit censoring opinions that didn't match mine. I found myself moving further and further towards progressivism because that was what I was reading on reddit, which I thought was the place with the freest speech on the internet. Moving to a place like Ruqqus has made me realize that the left actually wants to censor anyone that doesn't believe in what they believe in. That's why I'm a left-libertarian - I agree with the left's policies but I don't want to be part of the progressives' authoritarian movement. I may not agree with your views but I want you to at least have a place to state your opinions!
body_html: I'm personally borderline alt-left but I just got tired of reddit censoring opinions that didn't match mine. I found myself moving further and further towards progressivism because that was what I was reading on reddit, which I thought was the place with the freest speech on the internet. Moving to a place like Ruqqus has made me realize that the left actually wants to censor anyone that doesn't believe in what they believe in. post.title: A quick guide to what opinions Reddit tolerates and what opinions they hate.

body:
Conservatism isn't a philosophy. It's a relative position. Lenin and Stalin were radicals until they took power. Once they were running the show, all of a sudden they were the conservatives. Since you said "small government" I will assume you mean minarchism. Yes, I'd put minarchism next to anarchism.

In broad terms, I'd say the linear scale would look something like this:

Communism --> Fascism --> Democracy --> Republic --> Minarchism --> Anarchism
body_html:
Conservatism isn't a philosophy. It's a relative position. Lenin and Stalin were radicals until they took power. Once they were running the show, all of a sudden they were the conservatives. Since you said "small government" I will assume you mean minarchism. Yes, I'd put minarchism next to anarchism.

In broad terms, I'd say the linear scale would look something like this:

Communism --> Fascism --> Democracy --> Republic --> Minarchism --> Anarchism

post.title: A quick guide to what opinions Reddit tolerates and what opinions they hate.

body: You might as well be Hitler in their eyes, I assure you.  Free speech is hate! 🙄 This lib center is happy to see you on Ruqqus!
body_html: You might as well be Hitler in their eyes, I assure you. Free speech is hate! 🙄 This lib center is happy to see you on Ruqqus!

parent.body: I'm personally borderline alt-left but I just got tired of reddit censoring opinions that didn't match mine. I found myself moving further and further towards progressivism because that was what I was reading on reddit, which I thought was the place with the freest speech on the internet. Moving to a place like Ruqqus has made me realize that the left actually wants to censor anyone that doesn't believe in what they believe in. That's why I'm a left-libertarian - I agree with the left's policies but I don't want to be part of the progressives' authoritarian movement. I may not agree with your views but I want you to at least have a place to state your opinions!

I may not agree with your views but I want you to at least have a place to state your opinions!
